p.seg:
BIENNIAL REPORT
OF THE
State Treasurer
TO THK
GOVERNOR
OF THE
STATE OF NEBRASKA.
v
•
NOVEMBKR 3O, 1QOO.
OMAHA, NEB.:
PRESS OK OMAHA PRINTINfi OO.
1900.

State Treasurer
Deputy Treasurer
First Book-keeper Second Book-keeper
Miss Alice Tucker,
Stenographer
J. B. Meserve,
Sam'l Patterson, C. Q. De France, C. J. West,

REPORT.
State of Nebraska, Treasury Department, 1 Lincoln, Nebraska, December 4, 1900. j
To His Excellency, William A. Poynter, Governor:
Sir: — In compliance with Section 22, Article 5, of the Constitution, I have the honor to submit herewith the biennial report of this department, showing the receipts and disbursements, excluding transfers, from December 1, 1898 to
Balance on hand at close of business Nov
ember 30, 1900 $ 615,018.34
In accordance with Section 3, Chapter 79 of the Compiled Statutes which provides for the distribution of the Temporary School fund on the third Monday in May and the first Monday in December, the amount of money in the Temporary School fund will be certified to the state superintendent on the 3rd of December and paid out during this month. This law should be amended so that the apportionment should be made in April and October instead of May and December. The fiscal year ends November 30, and the treasurer's biennial report is made at that date. If the apportionment was made April and October it would be all closed up at the end of the
November 30, 1900, inclusive.
Balance as per report of 1898 $ Received from November 30, 1898, to Nov-
624,523.43
ember 30, 1900 ...
5,413,656 . 26
Total $
6,038,179.69
Disbursements from November 30, 1898, to
November 30, 1900
5,423,161.35

4
RKPORT OF THE
fiscal year and properly reported. As it is now a part of the business laps over into the next term.
The bonded indebtedness of the state having been entirely paid, there is now in the Sinking fund $56,165-23 which should be transferred to the General fund and authority given to the state treasurer to hereafter credit this fund to the General fund as it comes in from the county treasurers in payment of taxes. There is no levy being made for the Sinking fund, but there is still some due from back taxes. There is $2, 358. 00 in the Penitentiary Land fund. This money arises from rent of lands which were set aside for the building of the penitentiary ; small tracts of said lands have not been sold and there should bp authority given to either transfer these rands to the school or use this money arising therefrom for the improvement of the penitentiary. I called attention to this in my last report but the legislature took no action thereon and the money is still accumulating and cannot be used for any purpose unless the legislature does act thereon. In my last report we still had $153,267.35 of state bonds. These have been entirely paid, making a total of $468,267.35 paid and cancelled during my two terms of office. We still have a floating indebtedness consisting of warrants drawn on the General fund, which arises from the fact that we have a large amount of back taxes which have not been collected but against which warrants have been issued. The School fund holds $1,165,762.12 of this amount; the balance $561,747.60 is held by different individuals. The fact that the School fund has absorbed so much of this floating indebtedness has virtually put the state upon a cash basis as far as any advantage could be obtained by paying cash for all purchases made by the state for the running of the state institutions, and the loss to the state from payingthe interest is reduced to the minimum, as the interest goes back to the state and is distributed to the tax-payers through the Temporary School fund ; but unless there is a thorough revision of the revenue law there should be an amendment to our present law to levy seven (7) mills for General fund instead of five (5), as the present levy doe

1
not keep up with the appropriation, and there should not only be an effort to keep from getting into debt farther but to gradually reduce this floating debt until it is all paid up. The state has bonds and secureties as an investment for its educational funds amounting to $4,365,544.63. Since my last report we have bought county bonds to the amount of $268,868.62. We have bought General fund and University fund warrants to the amount of $1,238,288.26. Making a total investment in four years of $2,245,356.79. I called attention in my last report to the great difficulty in the future to invest the educational trust funds under our present law; and unless means are taken to amend the constitution so that we can buy other, securities than are now allowed by law, it will become harder every year to keep these funds invested. In my last report I recommended the reduction of interest upon General fund warrants from five to four per cent, thinking that would make the rate low enough so that such warrants could be purchased as investment for these funds without paying a premium thereon; but there is so much money accumulating in these funds that it has been found impossible to keep it invested without paying quite a heavy premium for warrants. Inasmuch as there will be more money in the future to invest than there has been in the past, I would recommend that the rate of interest be reduced to three per cent. In this connection I hope I may be pardoned if I should evince some pride in recalling that when I first came into the office a five per cent warrant was selling at ninty-three to ninty-six cents on the dollar, and at this time a four per cent warrant commands a premium of one per cent.
By reducing the rate of interest from five to four per cent, on General fund warrants there has been a saving to the state in the last two years of over thirty thousand dollars; by requiring the county treasurers to remit each month instead of twice a year as formerly there has been a saving of interest, in the last four years, of something over seventy thousand -dollars.

6
As the law now reads, interest upon bonds issued for irrigation purposes is made payable at the state treasurer's office and county treasurers are directed to remit to the state treasurer all moneys collected for this purpose. This is a county matter and not state, and the law should be amended so as to make the interest payable at the county treasurer's office the Same as school district and precinct bonds. If it is paid into the state treasurer's office it would have to lie over until the next session of the legislature before it could be paid out, as no money can be paid out of the state treasury without an appropriation by the legislature.
In order to clear away the financial wreck which 1 found in the office when I first came into it, we charged off into a Suspended Account $673,641 . 35. Through the untiring efforts of Attorney General Smyth a portion of this Suspended Account has been recovered amounting to $45,798.69.
For further details I respectfully refer you to the tables making up the remainder of this report.
In conclusion I wish to repeat what I said in my last report, " that I should not show a proper appreciation of good work done if I did not say that the satisfactory conduct of tliis office is in a large measure due to my office force, who have been efficient, prompt, and loyal at all times during the past two years."
Respectfully submitted,
J. B. Meserve,
State Treasurer.

7

STATEMENT No. 2.
Detailed statement showing amounts recovered from December i, 1898, to November jo, 1900, for the state of items heretofore transferred to the Suspended Account.
The Suspended Account was opened March 31, 1897, bytransferring to it from several funds such amounts in those funds unavailable because of bank failures or the failure of Ex-Treasurer Bartley to turn over the trust funds in full to his successor. The purpose of opening the Suspended Account was to eliminate all unavailable items from the different funds, so that the balances shown by the general ledger on hand at any time would be exactly the same as the cash on hand and in bank.
A complete statement of the Suspended Account follows:

S'ayne County Court House bonds Issued December 1, 1898; $2,500 due in 1904, and a like amount each year thereafter; final payment due in 1913. Interest at five per cent. (5% ), payable semi-annually on June 1 and December 1, at fiscal agency, New York. Purchased February 13, 1899, at a premium of S3, 234. 50, less accrued interest $365.58, making $2,868.62 net premium.
